name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: So no, unity doesn’t mean extending a hand to people who would either actively or passively cut it off. And family doesn’t mean a necessity to keep those bonds live. So let’s just stop with that narrative of shaming those who do as being shortsighted or petty or unempathetic.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: Not “our uncle” or any kind of other familial designation. Sometimes family is toxic and undermine our entire right to existence. And in such a scenario, not only do we have precedent to cut them out, but sometimes its even REQUIRED.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: And Lavan, the more insidious of the two, who constantly abuses and swindles Yaakov while saying “we’re family, can’t we get long”, is not even counted as family any more. “An Aramean tried to destroy my forefather” we say in the Haggadah.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: And Yaakov says no to both and cuts them both out of his life. It’s a Jewish dictum that “Esav will always hate Yaakov”, even through overtures of “unity” and “friendship”.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: But then there’s Yaakov and Esav and Lavan. That break goes far beyond “ideology”. Each of them are dedicated to destroying Yaakov, his family, and their way of life. Each make overtures to Yaakov under the guise of “unity” and “family”.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: Yishmael is a rapscallion, but he continues to listen and grow, not only taking his father’s advice on his choice of wives, but even growing and correcting himself that he and his brother can bury their father together.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: In fact, even in Sodom, when the chips are down, Lot espouses the compassion he learned in Avraham’s house by inviting in guests even though the entire society around him is like “Nah, son. Also, we’ll kill you for that.”

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: See, in the Avraham/Lot scenario, they disagree ideologically, but Lot’s ideology doesn’t inherently threaten Avraham, his life, or his family.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: But then there’s Yaakov and Lavan. And Yaakov and Esav.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))
description: Black • Jewish • Orthodox • Writer • Speaker • Consultant • Rabbi • 12th lvl Social Justice Sorcerer (Divine Soul) • #ActuallyAutistic • also @akaMaNishtana
tweet: Now sure, there are stories of reconciliation. Avraham keeps Lot at a distance, but still comes to his rescue when he’s captured. Yishmael gets banished, but gets better, even reaching a level of reconciliation with Yitzchak that they both bury Avraham together.

tweet: In fact, the reason why kaddish is only said for 11 months after the passing of a parent is that to say it for the full 12 months would intimate that the parent was among the most wicked and needing of that protection for the full 12 months, thus being disrespectful.

name: (((Ma Nishtana)))

tweet: The only thing that varies is the length of time spent, and only the most wicked stay the full 12 months. The act of saying kaddish for the deceased acts as a merit for their soul and provides a buffer from the pains of Hell.
